Deaths Dance isn’t damage reduction, it’s traded upfront damage for damage taken later.

That's true, but the healing you get from the item essentially mitigates the extra damage you would take later. It also gives you an extra few seconds to survive a burst combo that would otherwise be fatal.
But it isn't damage reduction. The distinction is REALLY important.

Technically it is damage reduction.

That 1k incoming burst hits you for 700.  That's 30% instantaneous damage reduction.  

You will then take a dot over several seconds equal to the 30% damage that was reduced, but note just from the set up of the situation, the damage you take is actually 30% of incoming burst - hp regen over 3 seconds.

If you had exactly 1k hp, and 5 regen per 5 (super low stats, most champions by the time they have 1k hp have noticeably more regen) and took 1k damage without Death's Dance, you're flat out dead at t=o. 

With Death's Dance damage reduction alone, and no healing at all, you will live, with 3 hp at t=3s.

To pretend that no damage reduction occured is folly, if it didn't you would have died instantaneously in this scenario.
Just because you'll take 1/3 of the mitigated damage as an additional DoT each second for 3 seconds does not mean the instanteous damage reduction was not applied.  To say that it isn't damage reduction misconstrues how the passive actually works, as it most certainly *IS* damage reduction and is even coded as a 30% damage reduction to all incoming hits.  

Yes, you will eventually take damage equal to this reduction, that does not invalidate the reduction (and all the effects of said reduction) this has.  For example, if you do 1k physical damage with 20% lifesteal, you would heal for 200 health, would you not?  But now, say you deal "1k damage" to a target with Death's Dance?  You actually only deal 700 in the first hit, and heal for only 140-- notice, a full 60 hp less, or 30% less healing; you also will not heal for the damage Death's Dance does to them as a DoT, effectively losing out on 30% of the healing you should be able to do.

People who say it isn't damage reduction do not know what they are talking about, and are simply confused on the matter.

In the first example, you would need to deal 1430 total damage before Death's Dance's damage reduction to instantly kill them; a full 43% more damage required.  Yeah, totally isn't damage reduction at all.  That would be crazy talk.

"Technically" 
Yes, it AT THE TIME reduces the damage, however overall and as the item it is, it's not damage reduction. It buys you time to get heals and etc, but it's not like armor. You don't "lose" that damage, it still happened/is going to happen.

Damage reduction as most know it as, is actually preventing damage from happening from an amount that has been inflicted. This doesn't "prevent" as much as mitigates it for a short time. This should be known as a Damage Mitigation item instead. 

It's useful, but it really isn't damage reduction as most people see it, it's not confusion as much as incorrect terminology being applied to the item in question in the first place and people fighting over the definition while everyone understands the benefits and cons of such an item. 

I'd much rather have a 30% damage reduction item, as would most; I'd say. Which is why there's arguments happening. 

Again I'm not saying there's no benefit to that 30% being taken and then reapplied as per your example, but 'initial reduction' shouldn't really be classified as "Damage reduction" because it's not actually changing the value. It's like a loan of health, you have to pay it back; it has no interest which makes it the best loan. But most people would just want the money free to begin with/30% never needing to be payed back.

Except for in the example I gave, and in any other case similar, it functions exactly like damage reduction.  You only heal for the damage the initial hit does, which is 30% less than what it would otherwise be.  Abilities that increase their damage based on the damage you do during their duration factor in the initial hit at 70% its value due to Death's Dance's "total-not damage reduction."  

It's coded as damage reduction.  It *IS* damage reduction.  It just has extra steps.

Imagine a burst shield that slowly decays over 3 seconds like Sterak's passive or something.  Say it shields for 1000 to start, scales down to 0 after 3 seconds to keep it nice and simple.  Now, it would be wrong to call that a 3 second 1,000 damage shield perhaps, but it's worth pointing out that it can block 1,000 damage initially.  I know its not the strongest comparison, but when the item in many cases functions exactly like damage reduction to the point where the initial effect is virtually and entirely indistinguishable from damage reduction, it truly makes more sense imho to realize that it *is* damage reduction, and that {{item:3812}} then has an additional damage over time component to offset how broken the item otherwise would be.

Except not, healing damage that is dealt isn't damage reduction, it's damage that's done and then healed. You're not reducing anything like I said you're MITIGATING it. Reduction would imply it gets rid of it completely. You're not lessening the damage, you're lessening the blow AT THE TIME which is entirely different. Which is why it's not damage reduction like armor.

If armor gives you 30% damage reduction from a 100 auto, that means only 70 damage hits. Which means you reduced 30 damage.

In the case of death's dance the value is STORED and then re-utilized as true damage later in a True damage DoT (1/3rd) 33.3%~ of the damage done/sec over 3 seconds. That is not reduction that's mitigation.

" Stores 30% of all physical and magic damage received, and is taken as damage over time true damage instead, dealing one-third of the stored damage every second." - Quoted from the Wiki.

That means it ALL comes back eventually, regardless of how you want to twist it. Healing the damage doesn't make it go away, because that health could have gone towards that 70% you lost in your example if it had been armor that blocked 30%, but in this case the healing has to heal 100% of the amount, just not all at once which is not reduction in the end, but mitigation. 

So if a user with death's dance had 100(1000) damage done to them, they take the 70(700), and then immediately applied is the additional 30(300) broken up into 3 seconds. meaning you get 10(100) damage almost immediately after and then 20(200) additional damage broken up over the next two seconds. The damage is STILL going to happen, you just don't take as much initially which is why it's different than reduction. It's not coded like reduction at all it's a stored value, that's reapplied.

Read what I actually said, and actually look at the specific example I had given before and that I am referencing here initially instead of talking completely past it because, well, I don't even know why.  Did you respond to the wrong one of my comments perhaps? 

You're completely missing the point that the damage dealer doesn't get lifesteal for the true damage dot being dealt, so they lose out on 30% of their lifesteal.

That DoT damage is not connected to the initial hit except that its value is calculated off of it.

People do not heal for that damage, or get any other benefits they would otherwise or normally get from that damage.  It does not count as damage they dealt to you, but simply damage you took.  This is a hugely important distinction that I have two comments, three now with this one discussing that you are completely talking past.  Read what I'm saying, or reply elsewhere where that isn't being discussed.

My original statement was that deaths dance does not grant damage reduction. And I will elaborate since it seems people don’t understand what I mean.

Death’s dance will not make you take less damage. It **delays** damage but it does not **mitigate** it. It rewards players for continuously fighting and pushing through the pain rather than running off with their tails between their legs. And yes it can save your life in a fight but so can literally every other lifesteal item.

If you are damaged and deal physical damage to heal the amount you would have lost, is that not a mitigation of the damage overall?

It's not, cause you're still gonna take that damage even if you heal. I'll simplify it to show why.
¤ Say you're at 1000 HP. You take 300 damage, but your lifesteal healed you for 100. You end up at 800 HP.
¤ With 30% damage reduction you only take 200 damage and drop down to 800 HP, but you still lifesteal for 100 so you're up to 900 HP.
¤ With Death's Dance you take 200 damage first then 100 damage over 3 seconds. You heal for 100 HP from your lifesteal. You end up at 800 HP.

So you still take the same amount of damage, nothing is reduced, but you're given time to heal if you can.

No, because if you take 70 damage with the other 30 being dealt over time and heal 30 exactly you still take the 100 damage, you just also happened to heal an additional 30, giving you a total of 70 health after the trade. But correlation is not causation.

If it where actual damage reduction that usual 100 damage shot would take only 70 damage and and if you where to heal then you’d have only lost a net total of 40 health

 It’s not reducing damage you take so it’s not damage reduction. You could heal more, you could heal less, you’re auto could be dodged or you could run away without attacking, but no matter what you’ll take the 100 damage.
